 bodily actions communicate particular messages, either in place of speech or
 together and in parallel with words. Gestures include movement of the hands,
 face, or other parts of the body. Gestures differ from physical non-verbal
 communication that does not communicate specific messages, such as purely
 expressive displays, proxemics, or displays of joint attention. Kendon, Adam. (2004) Gesture: Visible Action as Utterance.
 Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-83525-9 Gestures allow
 individuals to communicate a variety of feelings and thoughts, from contempt
 and hostility to approval and affection, often together with body language in
 addition to words when they speak.

Gesture processing takes place in areas of the brain such as Broca's and
Wernicke's areas, which are used by speech and sign language. Xu
J, Gannon PJ, Emmorey K, Smith JF, Braun AR. (2009).
